The resistance of a wire of length l and cross-sectional area A is given by R = ρ l/A, where ρ is the resistivity of the material from which the wire is made. The resistivity of a material varies with temperature; typically it increases with increasing temperature, so that the electric resistance of metallic conductors at room temperature also increases with increasing temperature. Different materials have different temperature coefficients of resistance (TCR). Measuring the resistance R of an electrical component at several different temperatures, and plotting the reciprocal of the resistance R-1 versus temperature T, will give a straight line with a negative slope equal to the TCR.
